title: Abstract: Unit 1 Lesson 15 – Americans' Time on Task
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15, titled 'Americans' Time on Task,' introduces students to the 'Time Use' Campaign, focusing on statistical thinking and data evaluation. The lesson engages students with an interactive multimedia graphic from The New York Times, which uses data from the American Time Use Survey, to explore how different groups spend their time. Students learn to critically evaluate data-driven reports by analyzing a Pew Research Center article, 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys.' Key vocabulary includes 'evaluate' and 'claim.' The lesson culminates in students beginning their own 'Time Use' Participatory Sensing campaign, collecting personal time-use data over several days using data collection devices. This hands-on experience, coupled with the analysis of professional data reports, aims to develop students' data literacy and critical thinking skills. The lesson also covers monitoring data collection progress using the IDS Campaign Monitoring Tool and sets the stage for Unit 1 Lab 1F and Unit 1 Lesson 16.

title: Unit 1 Lesson 15: Introduction to Time Use Campaign and Data Evaluation
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' serves as an introduction to the 'Time Use' Campaign. The primary objective is to engage students in exploring how individuals spend their time, drawing on real-world data. Students are introduced to the concept of statistical thinking by learning to critically 'evaluate' reports that make 'claims' based on data. This skill is developed through the analysis of a multimedia graphic from The New York Times and a detailed article from the Pew Research Center titled 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys.' The lesson emphasizes that learning to examine other analyses is a crucial part of statistical thinking. Students will begin their own data collection for the 'Time Use' Campaign, applying the skills learned in the lesson.

title: Objectives of Unit 1 Lesson 15: Exploring Time Use and Evaluating Reports
body: The core objectives for Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' are multifaceted. Students will be introduced to the 'Time Use' Campaign, which forms a significant part of their learning experience. A key activity involves exploring an interactive multimedia graphic, 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time,' which incorporates data from the American Time Use Survey. This exploration is designed to spark student interest in personal time allocation. Furthermore, a crucial skill development objective is to teach students how to 'evaluate' reports that present 'claims' based on data. This is achieved through a deep dive into the Pew Research Center's article, 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys,' where students will apply critical analysis to understand data sources, variables, and presented statistics. The lesson lays the groundwork for students to become informed consumers and producers of data-driven insights.

title: Materials and Resources for Unit 1 Lesson 15: Data Exploration and Analysis
body: For Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' students utilize various materials to engage with time use data. Essential resources include computers and data collection devices for interactive exploration and personal data gathering. A primary interactive material is 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time' multimedia graphic, available at https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/2009/07/31/business/20080801-metrics-graphic.html. Students also analyze the article 'Pew Research Center's Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys,' found at https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/04/24/teens-and-social-media-key-findings-from-pew-research-center-surveys/. A K-L-W Graphic Organizer (LMR_TR_K-L-W Chart) is provided to structure their learning from the article. The 'Time Use Campaign' guidelines (LMR_U1_Campaign_Time_Use) are also introduced, outlining the parameters for their personal data collection project. These materials collectively support the lesson's objectives of data exploration, evaluation, and personal data collection.

title: Key Vocabulary and Essential Concepts in Unit 1 Lesson 15
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' introduces students to critical vocabulary and essential concepts for developing statistical thinking. The vocabulary terms 'evaluate' and 'claim' are highlighted. To 'evaluate' means to think critically about something, particularly in the context of assessing data-based reports. A 'claim' is defined as a statement of something, which, in this lesson, refers to assertions made in articles that students must scrutinize. The essential concept underpinning the entire lesson is that 'Learning to examine other analyses is an important part of statistical thinking.' This concept is reinforced as students explore an interactive graphic on time use and thoroughly 'evaluate' the 'claims' and supporting data in a Pew Research Center article. Understanding these terms and concepts is fundamental to critically interpreting and engaging with statistical information.

title: Initial Exploration of American Time Use Data: The New York Times Graphic
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' students begin by familiarizing themselves with the 'Time-Use Campaign Guidelines' (LMR_U1_Campaign_Time_Use) and making predictions based on its big questions. Following this, they are informed about the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data collection on Americans' daily time use. Students then access and explore for 10 minutes an interactive multimedia graphic from The New York Times titled 'How Different Groups Spend Their Time' (https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/2009/07/31/business/20080801-metrics-graphic.html). This graphic, derived from the American Time Use Survey, visualizes how much time Americans over 15 spend on various activities like sleeping, eating, and socializing. The exploration prompts students to identify variables, interpret the graphic's information (including breakdowns by sex and ethnicity, and average time spent), and understand that the data originated from surveys where thousands of Americans recalled every minute of a day in 2008.

title: Analyzing Data from 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time' Graphic
body: During Unit 1 Lesson 15, students engage with 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time' interactive graphic to understand American time use. Their task involves answering specific questions to deepen their comprehension. They identify variables such as activities Americans spend time on (e.g., sleeping, eating, traveling, socializing). They learn that the graphic illustrates time spent by Americans over the age of 15, categorized by demographics like sex and ethnicity, and shows the percentage of Americans engaged in activities at specific times (e.g., 5% working at 6:00 am), as well as average time spent on an activity. Students discover the data originated from thousands of Americans aged 15 and older who took a survey in 2008, recalling their daily minutes. After individual exploration, students share interesting findings in pairs, fostering collaborative analysis of statistical data before proceeding to the 'Time Use' Campaign.

title: Evaluating Reports: Introduction to Pew Research Center's Article and K-L-W Chart
body: A core component of Unit 1 Lesson 15 is learning to 'evaluate' data-based reports. After exploring the NYT interactive graphic, students are introduced to the Pew Research Center's article, 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys' (originally referred to as 'The Washington Post' article, but corrected to Pew). They use a K-L-W Graphic Organizer (LMR_TR_K-L-W Chart) to structure their learning. Initially, students fill the 'Know' column with their existing knowledge about teens and social media. They then individually read the article (https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/04/24/teens-and-social-media-key-findings-from-pew-research-center-surveys/), completing the 'Learn' column as they read and the 'Want to Learn' column upon finishing. This structured approach helps them dissect and understand the article's content, preparing them for a critical evaluation of its statistical 'claims' and methodologies.

title: In-depth Evaluation of the Pew Research Article: Methodology and Variables
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15 guides students in teams to 'evaluate' the Pew Research Center's article on teens and social media. This evaluation focuses on the study's methodology. Students determine that the observed subjects were 1,316 U.S. teens (13 to 17-year-olds) and one parent from each household. The variables observed pertained to their experiences with social media, including time spent on platforms like YouTube, TikTok, Snapchat, Instagram, and Facebook, and the perceived effects of social media use. They identify that possible statistical questions included, for example, 'How much time per day does today’s typical 13 to 17-year-old spend on TikTok?' Students also ascertain that the data was collected by Ipsos, an online survey firm, between April 14 and May 4, 2022, on behalf of the Pew Research Center. This critical examination reinforces the essential concept of examining analyses as part of statistical thinking.

title: In-depth Evaluation of the Pew Research Article: Claims and Supporting Statistics
body: Continuing the critical 'evaluation' in Unit 1 Lesson 15, students analyze the 'claims' and supporting statistics presented in the Pew Research Center's article. They identify that the article made multiple claims, such as the initial claim: 'Majorities of teens report ever using YouTube, TikTok, Instagram, and Snapchat.' To support these claims, the article uses various statistics, which students pinpoint. Examples include: 'Two-thirds of teens report using TikTok, followed by roughly six-in-ten who say they use Instagram (62%) and Snapchat (59%).' Other statistics include, 'Six-in-ten teens say they think they have little (40%) or no control (20%) over the personal information that social media companies collect about them,' and 'Some 22% of teens think their parents are extremely or very worried about them using social media.' This exercise of connecting claims to their supporting data is crucial for developing students' ability to critically 'evaluate' statistical arguments.

title: Introduction to Unit 1 Campaign Time Use: Participatory Sensing and Data Collection
body: After critically evaluating existing data, Unit 1 Lesson 15 transitions students to active data collection through the 'Time Use' Participatory Sensing campaign (LMR_U1_Campaign_Time_Use). Students are informed that they will begin collecting data about their own time use, moving from analyzing others' data to generating their own. The campaign encourages students to use smart devices or a web browser, logging into the application and navigating to the 'Campaigns' section to add the 'Time Use' campaign. A reminder is given to refresh if campaigns are not immediately visible. This participatory element is designed to give students first-hand experience in data generation, which is a foundational aspect of statistical inquiry, building upon the critical 'evaluation' skills they've developed earlier in the lesson.

title: Guidelines for Student Data Collection in the Unit 1 Campaign Time Use
body: For the 'Time Use' Participatory Sensing campaign introduced in Unit 1 Lesson 15, specific guidelines are provided for student data collection. Students are instructed to track their daily activities via a log, emphasizing the need to account for all 1,440 minutes of their day. A helpful strategy is to split the log into three intervals: before school, after school, and in the evening, allowing for pauses to reflect on activities. Once a full day's log is complete, students must submit the corresponding survey. The campaign requires students to maintain a log for at least 5 days, ensuring that at least two of these days include a weekend, but not exceeding 10 days in total. These instructions ensure consistent and comprehensive data collection, which will be critical for subsequent analysis in the 'Time Use' Campaign.

title: Homework and Next Steps: Continuing Data Collection and Preparing for Unit 1 Lab 1F
body: The homework for Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' directly involves the 'Time Use' Campaign. Students are tasked with collecting data on their time use for the next five days using their smart devices or a web browser. This ongoing data collection is crucial for the campaign. The lesson also introduces upcoming activities: Unit 1 Lab 1F: 'A Diamond in the Rough' and 'Data Collection Monitoring.' Students are informed that they must complete Unit 1 Lab 1F prior to Unit 1 Lesson 16. Furthermore, they will be engaging in data collection monitoring using the IDS Campaign Monitoring Tool to track their progress. This reinforces the practical application of data collection and prepares them for further analysis and understanding of data management concepts, including the distinction between private and shared data.

title: Monitoring Student Progress in the Unit 1 Campaign Time Use
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' students and teachers learn about monitoring the progress of the 'Time Use' Participatory Sensing campaign. The IDS Campaign Monitoring Tool, accessible at https://portal.thinkdataed.org (via 'Campaign Monitor' sign-in), is introduced for this purpose. Teachers can use the 'User List' to sort by 'Total' and identify who has collected the most data. By clicking on the pie chart, insights into the number of active versus inactive users can be gained. The 'Total Responses' metric shows the overall data submissions. A 'Think-Pair-Share' strategy encourages students to brainstorm ways to increase data collection. This monitoring aspect provides real-time feedback on the campaign's progress and prepares students for a future discussion on private versus shared data after the collection phase is complete, before they embark on Unit 1 Lab 1F and Unit 1 Lesson 16.

title: Reinforcing Data Literacy: The Importance of Evaluating Claims and Sources
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15, 'Americans' Time on Task,' heavily emphasizes the importance of data literacy, specifically the ability to 'evaluate' statistical 'claims' and sources. Through activities like exploring the New York Times interactive graphic and analyzing the Pew Research Center article, students learn to question where data comes from, what variables are represented, and how conclusions are drawn. The lesson explicitly states that 'Learning to examine other analyses is an important part of statistical thinking.' By dissecting the Pew article, students identify who collected the data, how it was collected, the specific claims made, and the statistics used to support those claims. This critical approach empowers students to not only understand data but also to assess its validity and potential biases, a skill that is crucial both for the 'Time Use' Campaign and for navigating information in the real world.
